wordpressPost.title: WeSpire Employee Spotlight: Charlie Ash
wordpressPost.content:
Any great organization requires outstanding people working together to fulfill that organization’t mission and vision. At WeSpire we are extremely fortunate to have a number of amazing colleagues, all working to bring purpose to employees at companies large and small around the world.

Every month we shine the spotlight on one member of the WeSpire team, giving you an ongoing glimpse into the workforce behind the most powerful employee-engagement platform on the market today.
Please meet Charlie Ash, Product Designer!

Q: What are the top five most-used apps on your phone?
A: Spotify, Instagram, Echofon, Google Maps, Venmo
Q: What do you appreciate most about your childhood?
A: First and foremost, the love and support of my parents; they encouraged me in every way and means possible. Additionally, something I never appreciated sufficiently at the time, but it was being able to grow up in such a naturally beautiful area as midcoast Maine. Being encouraged to spend time outside, to go hiking and swimming and sledding every day were opportunities I’m extremely grateful for. And I now relish every chance I can to go back!
Q: Tell us about your favorite teacher/coach/adult figure growing up. Why did they inspire you then, and what have you realized about them now?
A: Charlie Seymour, my middle school band teacher. I wasn’t a huge concert band enthusiast, but he made learning and playing music fun. What I realize now about him is he wasn’t just that he was fun, but that he chose a career based on his passion; his enjoyment and dedication to his craft shone through in his teaching.
Q: You have to go on vacation for two weeks, all expenses paid. Where to?
A: Either on a safari in southern Africa or backpacking through the Patagonia region of Argentina and Chile. Top two things on my global travels to-do list!
Q: If you were in charge, what would you fix?
A: Simple (and maybe stereotypical): peace. C’mon people! We should encourage thoughtful dialogue around conflict, not partisan gridlock in governments and on a senseless violence amongst nations.
Alternate answer: fix the countless archaic and inane rules and broken systems in professional sports.
Q: What’s the best Big Hairy Audacious Goal (BHAG) you ever heard of, and whose was it? (examples, for inspiration)
A: As Andrew wrote in his spotlight, Kennedy’s declaration to put a man on the moon was a pretty huge BHAG! Spending my formidable {editor LOL} years during the rise of the internet, another great example of a BHAG was Google’s mission to organize the world’s information and make it universally accessible and useful. The whole concept of what they’ve helped create seemed incomprehensible only a short time ago!
Q: When you’re at work, what’s the most interesting opportunity you have to solve a Big Hairy Audacious Problem (BHAP)?
A: As a designer it’s when I’m tackling a problem that I have no pre-envisioned solution for. Diving in with no knowledge of where the project could lead is both liberating and exhilarating. Additionally, I think the whole mission of WeSpire solving a BHAP’turning a focus on employee engagement from something companies could have into something they should have.
Q: When you went to college, did you have an idea of what you wanted to do?
A: None whatsoever. I majored in economics because’ well, looking back, I’m not sure why. I enjoyed it, but it was a somewhat arbitrary choice. I did always have an interest in design, and a decade later finally decided to pull the trigger and pursue it (thanks Startup Institute!)
Q: If you could hire a personal assistant tomorrow, what three questions would you ask him/or her in the job interview?
A: What interests you most about this position? What motivates you in life, both day-to-day and in the long-term? What’s your favorite thing to do on a day off?
Q: What, if anything, is too serious to be joked about?
A: As long as it’s in good faith and with the right company, nothing. I think it’s very important to have a good sense of humor and take nothing too seriously as long as you’re not intentionally hurting someone.
Q: What’s your favorite new vocabulary word?
A: Recently I’ve learned of the word whopperjawed (essentially means askew). Been trying to use it as much as possible since!
Q: What’s your favorite meal you made recently?
A: My dad worked at a restaurant while I was growing up and would often make a fantastic Caesar salad from scratch. I’m still working on perfecting it, but am getting better each time I try.
Q: Signature cocktail?
A: Gin and Tonic in the summer. Whisky with an ice cube in the winter.
Q: Ideal date night?
A: It starts by going on a road trip, maybe to go on a short hike, listening to and singing along to bad (read: awesome) 90s music. Afterwards it would be finding a delicious hole-in-the-wall restaurant with great cocktails and a diverse beer list, and spending the evening sipping drinks, eating food, and laughing our faces off in conversation.
Q: Greatest extravagance?
A: Treating myself by going out to a nice dinner once a month. Working up towards making a yearly trip to start checking off my travel bucket list.
Q: Ideal pet?
A: A dog that’s the perfect combination of wanting to go for hikes and run around, and willing to have a lazy Sunday napping on the couch. And not make me sneeze like crazy.
Q: What would constitute a perfect day for you?
A: Start the morning with a cup of coffee and a crossword puzzle on the coast of Maine, listening to the surf and smelling the salt water air. The day would consist of hiking or swimming with friends and family, maybe a boat ride or kayak excursion. End it with beers around a bonfire reminiscing about old memories and creating new ones. Throw a Red Sox game somewhere into the mix, and it’s as close to perfect as I could get!
(Note: after completion I just saw Ellie’s response to this question’ I’ll just say she has amazing taste.)
Q: If you were to die and come back as a person or thing, what do you think it would be?
A: Probably Stoffel the honey badger.
Q: If you could wake up tomorrow having gained any one quality or ability, what would it be?
A: The ability to engage in thoughtful and meaningful conversation with anyone on any topic, from quantum entanglement to which brand of seltzer water is best (Polar cranberry lime, duh).
Mad lib bio snapshot:
Charlie Ash was born in Rockport, Maine. He launched his career at Customer Value Partners, a consulting firm outside of Washington, DC, and his favorite manager had a habit of asking him to keep him young. He joined WeSpire because he’s extremely excited to make a difference in employee engagement, because he thinks the workplace experience should be an enjoyable and meaningful one. In his spare time, he likes to try new restaurants around the city. (Middle Eastern tapas spot Sarma and new gastropub/bar The Rising are recent favorites. His colleagues at WeSpire have no idea that he loves to listen to Red Sox games on the radio (even when a TV is available), is extremely good at learning raps to 90s hip hop songs, and has been to New Zealand seven times.
